prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 2
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous great detective, whose deductions never fail to surprise.
Character 3
Name: Yujin Mikotoba
Description: A medical school professor at the Imperial Yumei University. He's an authority in forensic medicine, and Miss Susato's father.
Character 4
Name: Seishiro Jigoku
Description: The Minister of Foreign Affairs and a judge of the Supreme Court of Judicature in Japan. He's the man who acquitted me when I was once accused of murder.
Character 5
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 6
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Supposedly, the souls of those he prosecutes are eternally damned, one way or another.
Character 7
Name: Gina Lestrade
Description: A mostly reformed pickpocket who's now a self-appointed 'detective inspector'. She's really making waves in her new apprenticeship.
Character 8
Name: Evie Vigil
Description: A client who has engaged the services of Mr Sholmes. She has asked the great detective to help track down her missing husband.
Character 9
Name: Daley Vigil
Description: A man who's disappeared without a word to his family. He was the former chief warder of Barclay Prison.
Character 10
Name: Barry Caidin
Description: The governor of Barclay Prison. It seems he was good friends with Professor Mikotoba during the Japanese man's time in Britain as a visiting student.
Character 11
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: A murdered Scotland Yard inspector. He was stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 12
Name: Kazuma Asogi
Description: My best friend, who I had believed to be dead. He lost his memory somehow, but has now materialised as a prosecutor in the British courts.
Character 13
Name: Gossip
Description: A pedlar plying his trade on Fresno Street. He seems to make his money selling interesting items of news to passers-by.
Character 14
Name: Venus
Description: A pedlar plying her trade on Fresno Street. She seems to make her money selling meagre little fireworks to children.
Character 15
Name: Sandwich
Description: A mysterious 'signpost' who can be found on Fresno street. He looks familiar somehow...
Character 16
Name: Fabien de Rousseau
Description: The fraudster behind the Red-Headed League swindle, who was caught by Mr Sholmes. He derives from the French aristocracy, it seems.
Character 17
Name: Peppino de Rossi
Description: A lackey of de Rousseau and conspirator in the Red-Headed League swindle. The third son of a great Italian landowner.
Character 18
Name: Maria Gorey
Description: The daughter of Dr Sithe who's also a coroner like her mother. She carries out all the autopsy work on corpses.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Red-Headed League Article
Description: An advertisement from the newspaper that's entitled 'To the Red-Headed League'. It seems somewhat suspicious in nature.
Evidence 2
Name: Photograph of Mr Vigil
Description: A photographic print received from Mrs Vigil in order to aid with locating her missing husband. He appears to have no particularly distinctive facial features.
Evidence 3
Name: Letter of Introduction
Description: A note of introduction on our behalf from Professor Mikotoba to Governor Caidin. Hopefully now he'll be willing to talk to us. A note of introduction on our behalf from Professor Mikotoba to Governor Caidin. It's written on the back of a ticket for passage on a steamship.
Evidence 4
Name: Dismissal Notice
Description: The harsh reprimand incurred by Mr Vigil ten years ago that resulted in him losing his job as chief warder of Barclay Prison.
Evidence 5
Name: Red Hairpiece
Description: A flame-red wig found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Presumably it belonged to Inspector Gregson...
Evidence 6
Name: Candelabrum
Description: A candelabrum from the wall of the room on Fresno Street where the inspector was found dead. The top of one of the candles appears to have been blown off.
Evidence 7
Name: Revolver
Description: The murder weapon that was found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Probably best to avoid handling it.
Evidence 8
Name: Policeman Figurine
Description: A small and rather endearing model of a British policeman found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. A model of a British policeman found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Giving it a twist causes a key-like shaft to pop out from the base.
Evidence 9
Name: Framed Photograph
Description: A photographic print of a smiling Mrs Vigil in her younger years. It was found on a desk at the scene of the crime.
Evidence 10
Name: Gregson's Photograph
Description: An old photographic print displayed rather prominently in Inspector Gregson's office, as if it was a treasured memory. An old photographic print displayed rather prominently in Inspector Gregson's office. The person on the left is Lord Klint van Zieks.
Evidence 11
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: Inspector Gregson's autopsy report, stating that death was instant, resulting from a bullet shot at close range. The autopsy report from the examination of Inspector Gregson's body. According to the coroner, Dr Gorey, an accurate estimation of the time of death is not possible.
Evidence 12
Name: Crime Scene Floor Plan
Description: A plan of the small room in the building of flats on Fresno Street where the body of the victim, Inspector Gregson, was found.
Evidence 13
Name: Noticeboard
Description: A free-standing noticeboard completely covered in notes and articles relating to victims of the Reaper of the Bailey. A free-standing noticeboard completely covered in notes and articles relating to victims of the Reaper. There is a bloody handprint on the back side.
Evidence 14
Name: Venus Firecracker
Description: The Venus Special firecracker consisting of one hundred smaller fireworks at sixpence each. What sort of bang could it make...? The Venus Special firecracker consisting of one hundred smaller fireworks at sixpence each. It goes off like a gunshot.
Evidence 15
Name: Photograph of the Victim
Description: A photographic print of the victim, Inspector Gregson. His body appears to be tightly curled up and there's a red hairpiece on his head.
Evidence 16
Name: Gregson's Pocket Watch
Description: Inspector Gregson's pocket watch that he wound without fail every single day. It's no longer ticking and the glass over the face is cracked. Inspector Gregson's pocket watch that he wound without fail every single day. Having wound it up, it's started ticking again.
Evidence 17
Name: Inspector's Identification
Description: The identification of a man claiming to be a detective inspector, confiscated by Mr de Rousseau and Mr de Rossi. Inspector Gregson's police identification. It's the official warrant card issued to him by Scotland Yard.
Evidence 18
Name: Commemorative Photograph
Description: A photograph taken in the foyer of the Great Waterloo Hotel on the morning of Professor Mikotoba and Judge Jigoku's arrival in London for the symposium.
Evidence 19
Name: The Asogi Papers
Description: The last will and testament of Genshin Asogi that Mr Vigil claims disappeared after the convict's execution. Apparently Mr Asogi described it as 'the only weapon I have left'. The last will and testament of Genshin Asogi that Mr Vigil claims disappeared after the convict's execution. It seems there was a third page to it.
Evidence 20
Name: Gregson's Trunk
Description: Inspector Gregson's metal travelling trunk that was removed from the scene, but subsequently recovered by Gina.
Evidence 21
Name: Passport
Description: A passport document that was in Inspector Gregson's possession. It was issued for travel to France the day before his body was discovered.
Evidence 22
Name: Klint's Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the final victim of the infamous Professor. The report was authored by Dr John H. Wilson. The report from the autopsy of the Professor's final victim. It's signed by Dr John H. Wilson who carried out the procedure, though Professor Mikotoba actually penned the report.
Evidence 23
Name: Iris's Lucky Charm
Description: A little doll of Mr Sholmes in hare form. I've been told to tug its ears if I run out of options in the trial today...
Evidence 24
Name: Great Sword 'Karuma'
Description: The illustrious blade passed down through generations of the Asogi clan. The prized sword's tip has a small piece missing.
Evidence 25
Name: Evacuation Drill Itinerary
Description: A notice about a practice evacuation to be carried out by the crew of the SS Grouse the night before the ship arrived in Dover. It was found in Judge Jigoku's cabin.
Evidence 26
Name: Small Component
Description: A small machine part that Mr Sholmes found in Judge Jigoku's cabin on the SS Grouse. A small machine part that Mr Sholmes found in Judge Jigoku's cabin on the SS Grouse. It's now clear that it's the missing 'crown' of Inspector Gregson's pocket watch. * (This update to the description is entirely optional, and can only be achieved by examining anywhere on this evidence, then the tip on Gregson's Pocket Watch before the former evidence is specifically presented in court. However, this method still occurs in Story Mode.)
Evidence 27
Name: Telegram from Japan
Description: A telegram from Inspector Hosonaga in Japan with details of the telegram he managed to locate by stealing into Judge Jigoku's office.
Evidence 28
Name: Mr Asogi's Ring
Description: A ring belonging to Genshin Asogi found in Lord Klint van Zieks's stomach during the autopsy. The claws clasping the gem look sharp enough to cause a very nasty scratch.
Evidence 29
Name: Klint van Zieks's Will
Description: The last will and testament of Lord Klint van Zieks that has been hidden inside the great sword Karuma for years. A trump card left behind by Genshin Asogi.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: We saw the whole thing from start to finish, we did. Everything from the moment they went in the building.
Person: Gossip
Testimony 1
Testimony: It was less than a minute after the Reaper had gone inside that we all 'eard a big bang.
Person: Venus
Testimony 2
Testimony: Seems to m-me that quick-to-talk is quick-to-walk. Gossip couldn't wait to go and see what had happened.
Person: Sandwich
Testimony 3
Testimony: I ran into the room and there he woz. The Reaper, gun in hand, standin' over the dead body!
Person: Gossip
Testimony 4
Testimony: I slipped over and got blood on my hand, so I quickly wiped it off on the floor.
Person: Gossip
Testimony 5
Testimony: I was scared 'alf to death, me. So I ran off to find a copper.
Person: Venus

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, so I'm trying to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. Let me start by understanding the characters, evidences, and testimonies provided.

First, the characters involved are a mix of legal professionals, suspects, and witnesses. The main focus is on the murder of Inspector Gregson, which seems to be the central case here. The evidences include various items like a red hairpiece, a candelabrum, a revolver, a photograph of the victim, and a pocket watch. There's also a detailed floor plan of the crime scene and an autopsy report.

Looking at the testimonies, Gossip claims to have seen the Reaper (Barok van Zieks) with a gun standing over the victim. Venus, another witness, mentions hearing a bang and finding blood on her hand, which she wiped off. Sandwich corroborates that Gossip ran to find a copper after the incident.

Now, the evidence that stands out is the autopsy report (Evidence 11), which states that the cause of death was a bullet wound from close range, but the time of death couldn't be accurately determined. The candelabrum (Evidence 6) was found at the crime scene with a candle's top blown off, suggesting an explosion.

Wait, the candelabrum's candle being blown off might indicate a bomb or some explosive device. The testimony from Gossip and Venus about hearing a bang and seeing the Reaper with a gun could be conflicting with the evidence of an explosion. If the death was caused by a gunshot, as per the autopsy, but the candelabrum suggests an explosion, there's a contradiction.

So, the candelabrum (Evidence 6) and the testimony about hearing a bang (Testimony 1) might contradict each other. The evidence suggests an explosion, while the testimony points to a gunshot. Therefore, the candelabrum's presence and the witness's testimony about a bang might not align.
</think>

Testimony 4

cot:
Alright, let's dive into this problem. I'm faced with a list of characters, evidences, and testimonies. My task is to find a pair of evidence and testimony that contradict each other. The user has provided a lot of information, so I'll need to carefully analyze each piece to spot any inconsistencies.

First, I'll go through the list of characters to understand who's involved. There's Susato Mikotoba, a judicial assistant, and others like Iris Wilson, Herlock Sholmes, and several others. The case seems to involve a murder, with Inspector Gregson as the victim. There are also references to a firecracker and a noticeboard covered in crime-related notes.

Looking at the evidences, I see items like a red hairpiece, a candelabrum, a revolver, and a noticeboard. The noticeboard has a bloody handprint on the back. There's also a photograph of the victim, Inspector Gregson, with a red hairpiece on his head.

Now, examining the testimonies, Gossip and Venus provide alibis, but their statements might not directly relate to the evidence. Sandwich's testimony mentions hearing a gunshot and running into the room, finding the Reaper with a gun. Gossip claims he didn't know about the noticeboard and only wiped his hand on it. Venus says she doesn't know anything and was selling fireworks. Sandwich's testimony suggests he's unsure about the noticeboard's relevance.

The key here is to find a contradiction between an evidence and a testimony. The evidence about the noticeboard with a bloody handprint and the testimonies from Gossip and Venus not knowing about it might be conflicting. However, the main contradiction seems to be between the noticeboard's description and Gossip's testimony denying knowledge of it.

But wait, looking closer, the noticeboard's evidence states it was covered in crime-related notes and had a bloody handprint. Gossip's testimony says he didn't know about it, which contradicts the evidence's existence. Therefore, the contradiction is between Evidence 13 (Noticeboard) and Testimony 0 (Gossip's denial).

However, upon re-reading, Gossip's testimony doesn't directly deny the noticeboard's existence but says he didn't know about it. This might not be a direct contradiction. The main contradiction is likely between the noticeboard's presence and Gossip's claim of ignorance.

But I think the strongest contradiction is between Evidence 13 (Noticeboard) and Testimony 0 (Gossip's statement about not knowing anything). Gossip's testimony doesn't mention the noticeboard, implying he wasn't aware of it, which contradicts the evidence showing it was present and had a handprint.

Alternatively, the noticeboard's description and Gossip's testimony don't directly contradict each other since he didn't mention it, but his testimony focuses on the crime scene. The contradiction might lie elsewhere, perhaps in the timeline or physical evidence.

After careful consideration, the most direct contradiction is between Evidence 13 (Noticeboard) and Testimony 0 (Gossip's statement about not knowing anything). Gossip's testimony doesn't mention the noticeboard, which was found at the scene, indicating he might have interacted with it, contradicting his claim of ignorance.

But I'm not entirely sure. Maybe the contradiction is elsewhere. Let me check other pairs. Evidence 5 (Red Hairpiece) and Testimony 1 (Venus's statement about selling fireworks that make gunshot sounds). The red hairpiece was found on the victim, which might contradict Venus's testimony about the firecracker's sound.

However, the firecracker's description says it makes a gunshot sound, which matches Venus's testimony. This might not be a contradiction. The key contradiction is likely between the noticeboard's evidence and Gossip's testimony.

After analyzing, the contradiction is between Evidence 13 (Noticeboard) and Testimony 0 (Gossip's denial of knowledge). Therefore, the answer is {"evidence": 13, "testimony": 0}.
</think>

Description: The last will and testament of Lord Klint van Zieks that has been hidden inside the great sword Karuma for years. A trump card left behind by Genshin Asogi.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: We 'ad more zan one thousand red-'eaded people assemble in ze park on Lime Street zat day.
Person: De Rousseau
Testimony 1
Testimony: But I don't recall the man in this-a photograph. Ay, capo?
Person: De Rossi
Testimony 2
Testimony: Non, I don't remember 'im. Obviously 'e is dead now. But I assure you, 'e was not in ze park.
Person: De Rousseau
Testimony 3
Testimony: Allora! This victim is-a nothing to do with us!
Person: De Rossi
Testimony 4
Testimony: You 'ave a lot to answer for, Peppino. It is your fault zat we got caught in ze first place.
Person: De Rousseau

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, so I'm trying to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other. Let's see... I need to look through the evidence and testimonies provided.

First, I'll go through each evidence and see what they say. Evidence 1 is about the Red-Headed League Article. It mentions an advertisement that seems suspicious. Testimony 0 says they had over a thousand red-headed people assemble in the park. 

Wait, so the evidence is about an advertisement for the Red-Headed League, which seems suspicious. Testimony 0 says they had over a thousand red-headed people assemble in the park on Lime Street. But the evidence says the article is suspicious, and the testimony claims a large gathering of red-headed people.

Hmm, maybe the evidence is pointing towards the article being a fake or part of a scam. The testimony claims a big event happened with many red-headed people, but the evidence suggests the article was suspicious. So, if the article is fake, then the testimony about the gathering might be a lie.

So, the evidence (1) contradicts the testimony (0) because the article is fake, implying the gathering didn't happen. So, the answer is {"evidence": 1, "testimony": 0}.
</think>

Characters:

Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1

Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.

Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous great detective, whose deductions never fail to surprise.

Name: Yujin Mikotoba

Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.

Testimony: Ze, ze truth is, we took 'im prisoner and kept 'im for ze night at our secret 'ideout.
Person: De Rousseau
Testimony 1
Testimony: Even though I didn't sink 'e was a real detective, I, I was too scared to let 'im go zat day, just in case.
Person: De Rousseau
Testimony 2
Testimony: We took the man's identification from him and shut-a him in the room next to ours!
Person: De Rossi
Testimony 3
Testimony: Zere might 'ave been a little tussle, but we did 'im no 'arm. And ze next mornin', we let 'im go.
Person: De Rousseau

Testimony: He tried to escape, but the capo put-a the collare on him and dragged him back...like what he did-a to me, see?
Person: De Rossi

Person: De Rossi

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let me try to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other. I'm a bit new to this, so I'll take it step by step.

First, I need to understand the evidence and testimonies provided. The evidence includes things like a red-headed league article, photographs, and various items found at the crime scene. The testimonies are from different characters, each giving their account of events.

Looking at the testimonies, one of them mentions that the red-headed league advertisement was found on the noticeboard, but the defendant claims they don't know anything about it. The evidence shows that the advertisement was indeed present on the noticeboard, which the defendant is denying.

So, the evidence (the red-headed league article) suggests that the advertisement was there, while the testimony from the defendant claims they didn't know about it. This seems contradictory because the evidence shows the advertisement was present, but the defendant denies any knowledge of it.

Therefore, the evidence and testimony that contradict each other are the red-headed league article (Evidence 1) and the defendant's testimony (Testimony 0).
</think>

Testimony: Aye, I rent the room where that fella was found, it's true. For what difference it makes.
Person: Boone
Testimony 4
Testimony: I'm all alone in the world, me. I've no kinfolk or nothing. Why would I be involved in something like that?
Person: Gossip/Boone
Testimony 5
Testimony: Just look at me, eh. Doz it look like I could carry off a disguise with a face like this?
Person: Gossip/Boone

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Alright, so I'm trying to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. I've got a bunch of characters, evidences, and testimonies to consider. Let's go through them step by step.

First, I need to understand the situation. There's a murder investigation involving Inspector Gregson. The evidence includes things like a photograph of the victim, a candelabrum, a revolver, a framed photograph, and an autopsy report. The testimonies include statements from various characters like De Rousseau and De Rossi, who are involved in the Red-Headed League swindle.

Looking at the evidence, one of the key points is the Red-Headed League Article, which is an advertisement that seems suspicious. The photograph of the victim shows Inspector Gregson with a red hairpiece, which might be significant. The candelabrum from the crime scene has a blown-off candle tip. The revolver is the murder weapon found at the scene.

Now, the testimonies suggest that De Rousseau and De Rossi took the inspector prisoner and kept him in a secret hideout. They mention a tussle and dragging him back. The autopsy report indicates death was instant from a bullet shot at close range.

I think the key contradiction is between the Red-Headed League Article (Evidence 1) and the testimony from De Rousseau and De Rossi (Testimony 0). The article mentions the Red-Headed League, which the defendants are part of. Their testimony claims they were involved in keeping the inspector prisoner, which ties into the Red-Headed League's activities.

So, the evidence of the article and the testimony about their involvement in the League might contradict each other because the article suggests they were part of a larger scheme, while their testimony tries to downplay their involvement.
</think>
